timeline.message:
Crashlytics Analytics Connector realtime fixes

Refactor the Breadcrumbs receiver to listen for app exception events,
which enables us to block app shutdown until we've confirmed that
Firebase Analytics has received the app exception event.

Because Firebase Analytics serializes events asynchronously, it was possible
(and in fact quite common) for the defaultUncaughtExceptionHandler to close
the app BEFORE Firebase Analytics was finished writing the app exception event
to disk, which ultimately caused the event to be lost. Now Crashlytics waits
for the FA listener to fire with an app exception event before shutting down.

The 2000ms timeout was chosen somewhat arbitrarily; in practice the callback
is received within 100ms or so, and it does not block at all if Firebase
Analytics is not present.

timeline.bodyText: Can we make the 2000 a constant?
timeline.author: mrwillis21
mrwillis21

replies.bodyText: Probably onCrashlyticsOrigin. cls is an implementation detail. I'll update.
replies.author: mrichards

timeline.bodyText: Just to be technically correct 🤓 might be worth calling this app_exception event callback
timeline.author: mrwillis21

timeline.bodyText: Definitely thought this was a 1 for a minute and got very confused.
timeline.author: mrwillis21

timeline.bodyText: Stylistic point: if you use the null object pattern here, and swap in a no-op implementation whenever null is passed in the setter above, you'll only have to null-check in the setter, rather than on every event.
timeline.author: mrwillis21

replies.bodyText:
Funny enough, this was another reason why I was considering Set of listeners instead of just the single one. The empty loop would no-op.
I don't love the no object pattern as I find it confusing when it appears an event should be firing but there's no response anywhere. How  strongly do you feel about it in this particular place?
replies.author: mrichards

replies.bodyText: Not strong enough to have you change it now. :) Just a pattern I happen to prefer that would reduce the number of times this conditional is triggered.
replies.author: mrwillis21

replies.bodyText: In practice, though, this really should only happen once per session.
replies.author: mrwillis21

replies.bodyText: After a little synchronous chat: we settled on this being a relatively inconsequential matter of opinion and we're leaving it as-is.
replies.author: mrichards

timeline.bodyText: Would be great if we could pull these two paths out into named functions.
timeline.author: mrwillis21

timeline.bodyText:
As mentioned in chat, if you used a TaskCompletionSource instead of a countdown latch above, returned its Task from this method, and just resolved the task (via the completion source) in onCrashOriginEvent, you could simplify a lot of what's downstream.

You wouldn't need the extra Tasks.call with its own executor down below because this would just become part of the task chain already in the exception handler.
You wouldn't need the extra 2-second timeout here because the timeout would be handled by the exception handler task chain's timeout.
timeline.author: mrwillis21

replies.bodyText: (Going to do this on a future PR. See previous comment.)
replies.author: mrichards

timeline.bodyText: If this returned a task (as mentioned above), you could remove the extra Tasks.call above and turn this method (recordFatalFirebaseEvent) into a synchronous call (which still returns this task), then just chain the return value in the uncaught exception handler the same way.
timeline.author: mrwillis21

replies.bodyText: We both like this idea and will do this in a subsequent refactor, since it is going to require more extensive validation than we have time for before the next release. It mostly improves readability and not performance.
replies.author: mrichards

timeline.bodyText: nit: the "fire" prefix is... slightly overloaded in this codebase.
timeline.author: mrwillis21
